response.message: There's a related discussion about this blog post at https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/255983
Are blog comments borked? This is a test.

beyondcoding.io is very poorly made. I see a 2s FOUC and it takes a total of ~10s to load. It makes 2 XHR of style.less & base.less for no apparent reason… It gets 49% on google pagespeed and fails google's mobile-friendly test.

It seems like it was made by an… erm… "emerging computer programmer" that vamped on Stack Overflow just enough to get rep whores to piece together crappy jQuery code. This is embarrassing.
Looks nice for beginners. Wish I was there.
An Apple logo displayed prominently, and centrally, as the first starkly-contrasting element in the layout. Training them young, eh?

I think this is fabulous! There are so many skill outside of "coding" that a new developer needs to hone to be hirable!

And the comments on this blog are a great first step in teaching the soft skill of ripping apart another's work instead of pitching in to make it better!!
I love coding! This is Great work. Thank you for information. I wish you much success...

Great initiative, got me excited only to realize that this was for NY residents only.
Is there anyway you could make this online? Coding techniques would be appreciated anywhere.
this is worth a try.....
Unfortunately, not interesting at all for most of us - who are not New Yorkers.
You forgot the  tag for the site :)
Aah damn, wanted to say that you forgot the title tag for the site, got stripped from my last comment :p

Every time I see companies complaining about a 'skill gap' or a 'lack of candidates' I automatically translate it from business speak to plain English and it comes out as 'we won't pay for developers'.

There's a very easy and very simple way to get the programmers you want: pay them a good wage

That's not how supply and demand works, Clara. You don't instantly get more supply simply by raising the amount you're willing to pay. It takes years to train new developers. I work part-time in education, and we're simply not getting enough students through our IT programs to fill the need.
Can you define what is meant by "New York City area"? Can neighbors to the "NYC area" apply?
Don't need all this training, NYC employers simply need to pony up more money commensurate with the cost of living in one of the most expensive cities in the world...

This sounds like an interesting idea to help out new talent. But when I see words like "skill gap" I am reminded of how many hundreds of job postings I see on careers.stackoverflow.com which want the "everything" developer to make a multi-billion dollar "app" for entry-level wages. The problem isn't so much a lack of talented workers as it is unrealistic requirements and an underwhelming effort:compensation ratio.
Is this an online class room?

Looks like they want to get instant senior programmers out of juniors.
Where have I heard before we want things done fast at top quality.
Maybe all this demand for programmers is just a bubble.
Helping juniors is still good.
test comment
Only for NYC. What about others? Any chance in INDIA?

Bill The Lizard,

Actually, that is exactly how supply and demand works, by definition.  Increase the price you are willing to pay, and there will be a larger pool of candidates to choose from.  I understand if the capital does not want to get into a bidding war over mere fungible hired help, but that doesn't somehow negate supply and demand.

This does sound pretty great. I'm employed and not in NY, but I do wish they had something similar where I live. And I agree with @Jaime, regarding the soft skill of ripping apart each other's work. Welcome to I.T.!

"Unfortunately, not interesting at all for most of us – who are not New Yorkers."

Or Apple fanbois.

Blizzard,

That's not increasing the total supply, it's just taking developers away from another company. The demand is just moving around. That doesn't do anything to fix the underlying problem of not enough developers to fill the open positions.
What about in Bay AREA...
I would love to attend this training. I wish I was there in NYC.

When will we have one in London? 

There's no doubt that initiatives like this can be very beneficial to programmers starting their careers...

The endeavor is a noble and good one. 

I want to start such an endeavor in India because the workforce here truly lacks global exposure which does affect the outcome of projects. Any help or support is welcome.

What is the best way to contact the event organizers of this event?
Great that will enable and equip programmers to have a better understanding and also release there skills. Wonderful opportunity well done.

Where can I found the curriculum for this training?
Is there participant could choose their major in that training?
